channel.title: NYT > Books > Book Review
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Book Review: ‘The War Within a War,’ by Wil Haygood
item.description: Wil Haygood’s “The War Within a War” is a rare, illuminating look at the way the war shaped the struggle for equality back home.
item.dc:creator: Brent Staples
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
The War Within a War: The Black Struggle in Vietnam and at Home (Book)
item.media:description: American G.I.s carrying a wounded soldier near the Cambodian border in 1967.

item.title: Book Review: ‘A Better Life,’ by Lionel Shriver
item.description: As usual, Lionel Shriver sets out to puncture pieties, but “A Better Life” feels full of easy targets.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs

item.title: Saying Goodbye to the Mass Market Paperback
item.description: The mass market paperback, light in the hand and on the wallet, once filled airport bookstores and supermarket media aisles. You may never buy a new one again.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris

item.title: Book Review: ‘Poems From an Attic,’ by Iris Murdoch
item.description: The formidable novelist and philosopher, who died in 1999, thought her poetry was mediocre. It’s not.
item.dc:creator: Dwight Garner
item.category: Poems From an Attic: Selected Poems, 1936-1995 (Book)

item.title: The 10 Best Books of 2025
item.description: The staff of The New York Times Book Review choose the year’s top fiction and nonfiction.
item.category: The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny (Book)
There Is No Place for Us: Working and Homeless in America (Book)
Mother Emanuel: Two Centuries of Race, Resistance, and Forgiveness in One Charleston Church (Book)
A Marriage at Sea: A True Story of Love, Obsession, and Shipwreck (Book)
Wild Thing: A Life of Paul Gauguin (Book)

item.title: Hudson Talbott Dies at 76; Wrote and Illustrated Wide-Ranging Children’s Books
item.description: His book about time-traveling dinosaurs became a Steven Spielberg-produced movie, and he adapted the Stephen Sondheim musical “Into the Woods” for young readers.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Gabor Boritt, Refugee Who Became Expert on Lincoln, Dies at 86
item.description: He survived the Holocaust and Communist rule in Hungary, arrived penniless in New York and made himself into a pre-eminent Civil War scholar.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History
item.media:description: Gabor Boritt in 2006. At Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania, near the site of the 1863 battle that changed the course of the Civil War, he built a career around Abraham Lincoln.

item.title: Baking for Your Valentine? This Psychologist Would Like a Word.
item.description: Helen Goh, the British baker and therapist, thinks romantic treats can be tricky. She advises tailoring them to the length of your relationship.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times

item.title: Book Review: ‘Saraswati,’ by Gurnaik Johal
item.description: Gurnaik Johal follows seven characters in interconnected narratives about climate change and the rise of authoritarianism.
item.dc:creator: Siddhartha Deb
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some believe that the confluence of the Ganges and Yamuna Rivers in Prayagraj, India, once joined the legendary Saraswati River.

item.title: Can AI Chatbots Write Emotionally Rich Romance Books?
item.description: The romance industry, always at the vanguard of technological change, is rapidly adapting to A.I. Not everyone is on board.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Charlotte Coppin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author Coral Hart has become an evangelist for A.I.

item.title: Haruki Murakami Isn’t Afraid of the Dark
item.description: The author, who brought Japanese literature into the global mainstream, grapples with aging and his place in the world of letters.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Dana Scruggs for The New York Times

item.title: Suzannah Lessard Dies at 81; Stanford White Descendant Who Wrote a Haunting Family Memoir
item.description: Growing up in a family of secrets, on a compound designed by her great-grandfather, made her a writer who investigated the built world with a wary eye.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:credit: Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Suzannah Lessard in 1996, on the balcony of the Players club in Manhattan, designed by her great-grandfather Stanford White.

item.title: Michael Pollan Says Humanity Is About to Undergo a Revolutionary Change
item.description: The best-selling author grapples with big questions about A.I., consciousness and the distractions polluting our minds.
item.dc:creator: David Marchese
item.category: A World Appears: A Journey Into Consciousness (Book)
How to Change Your Mind: What the New Science of Psychedelics Teaches Us about Consciousness, Dying, Addiction, Depression, and Transcendence (Book)
item.media:credit: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times

item.title: Book Review: ‘This Is Not About Us,’ by Allegra Goodman
item.description: In her new novel in stories, “This Is Not About Us,” Allegra Goodman traces the small but vivid dramas of one sprawling Jewish family.
item.dc:creator: Jami Attenberg

item.title: Book Review: ‘Eradication,’ by Jonathan Miles
item.description: In his new novel, Jonathan Miles considers the complicated ethics and logistics of eliminating an invasive species.
item.dc:creator: Matt Bell

item.title: How Nintendo Became the Most Fun Video Game Company
item.description: Video games are big business, and the company behind Mario, Zelda and Pokémon may be the most important player, says the author of a new corporate history.
item.category: Super Nintendo: The Game-Changing Company That Unlocked the Power of Play (Book)
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Inset cover: via Knopf

item.title: Farewell, Pocket Books
item.description: Our books reporter Elizabeth A. Harris explores the disappearance of mass market paperbacks — and talks with Stephen King about what paperbacks have meant to him.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris, Léo Hamelin and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Graphic Novels for Raina Telgemeier Fans
item.description: Thirteen recommendations for fans of the Smile series.
item.dc:creator: Travis Jonker

item.title: Books Our Editors Loved This Week
item.description: Reading recommendations from critics and editors at The New York Times.
item.category: The Oak and the Larch: A Forest History of Russia and Its Empires (Book)
Everything Is Photograph: A Life of Andre Kertesz (Book)

item.title: Toni Morrison’s Best Books: A Guide
item.description: Her novels reveal a deeply American desire for freedom and adventure, and one of her work’s great joys lies in always finding something new to discover. Here’s where to start.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Chambers

item.title: Book Review: ‘A Killing in Cannabis,’ by Scott Eden
item.description: In “A Killing in Cannabis,” Scott Eden tells the story of a man who tried to straddle the lines between the legal and black-market cannabis worlds, with deadly consequences.
item.dc:creator: Tas Tobey
item.category: A Killing in Cannabis: A True Story of Love, Murder, and California Weed (Book)
item.media:description: As legal cannabis markets proliferate across the country, Scott Eden takes us back to a more lawless time.

item.title: Cristina Rivera Garza on Her Favorite Books and ‘Autobiography of Cotton’
item.description: “I love to fall asleep with a book nearby,” says the “Autobiography of Cotton” author. “Dreaming and reading merge in beautiful, uncompromising ways.”

item.title: Best One-Night Stand Romance Books, According to Hannah Bonam-Young
item.description: The best-selling author Hannah Bonam-Young recommends swoon-worthy love stories with spicy beginnings.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Bonam-Young

item.title: Book Review: ‘Bernie for Burlington,’ by Dan Chiasson
item.description: In “Bernie for Burlington,” Dan Chiasson’s affection for his subject risks turning history into a sales pitch.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Nazaryan
item.category: Bernie for Burlington: The Rise of the People's Politician and the Transformation of One American Place (Book)
item.media:description: Bernie Sanders, pictured here in his first term, served as the mayor of Burlington, Vt., from 1981 to 1989.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Family Snitch,’ by Francesca Fontana
item.description: In “The Family Snitch,” the reporter Francesca Fontana delves into her father’s criminal history — and their complicated, painful relationship.
item.dc:creator: Sylvia Brownrigg
item.category: The Family Snitch: A Daughter's Memoir of Truth and Lies (Book)

item.title: He Died at 49. His Collected Poems Rank With the Best of the 20th Century.
item.description: Larry Levis’s work, gathered in the expansive new book “Swirl & Vortex,” was equally concerned with the soul and the void.
item.dc:creator: Elisa Gabbert

item.title: Book Review: ‘Everything Is Photograph,’ by Patricia Albers
item.description: The pioneering photographer André Kertész is the subject of a new book by Patricia Albers.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Szalai
item.category: Everything Is Photograph: A Life of Andre Kertesz (Book)
